name: Idiopathic Trigeminal Neuralgia with Vascular Compression
chief_complaint: Sudden, severe electric shock-like pain on the right side of my face
symptoms: Episodic facial pain triggered by chewing or brushing teeth
Mild facial numbness after severe episodes
physical_findings: Normal cranial nerve exam between episodes

lab_results.MRI Brain with FIESTA sequence: Neurovascular conflict at trigeminal nerve root entry zone

treatment: Microvascular decompression surgery if medication fails
Gamma knife radiosurgery for non-surgical candidates
prognosis: Good with proper treatment, though may require long-term medication management or surgical intervention
description: A neuropathic pain disorder of the trigeminal nerve characterized by sudden, severe, brief stabbing recurrent episodes of pain in areas of the face supplied by one or more branches of the nerve. Often caused by vascular compression at the nerve root entry zone.
multiple_choice: Idiopathic Trigeminal Neuralgia with Vascular Compression
